imageadjuster
Class ImageAdjuster

java.lang.Object
  imageadjuster.ImageAdjuster

public class ImageAdjuster
extends java.lang.Object

Provides methods for adjusting brightness, contrast and gamma of images. Contains both high-level methods that operate directly on images, and low-level methods that operate on an internal color transformation matrix that can later be applied to images.

High-level routines can be identified as those that take an image as their first parameter. Low-level routines can be identified as those that take only an adjustment amount as a parameter.

The low-level routines are optimized for uses such as applying a predefined series of adjustments repeatedly, for example while processing video frames. It is possible to define the transformation once, then apply it multiple times, potentially resulting in condsiderable performance gains.

Version 0.05 - compile against Processing 1.0.3, primary difference is to remove support for imageMode==CORNERS (since Processing 1.0.3 itself no longer supports it)

Version:
0.04
Author:
David Bollinger, http://www.davebollinger.com

autoMaintainPixels

public boolean autoMaintainPixels
Indicates whether these routines should automatically maintain an image's pixels array by calling loadPixels() and updatePixels() as necessary.

The default is true, indicating that these routines will automatically load and update an image's pixels array every time it is accessed. However, there are certain scenarios where maintaining the pixels array manually may have performance advantages. In those cases, set this value to false, and pixel maintenance will not occur herein. It is then left to the user to manually ensure that the pixels array is adequately maintained.

Method Detail

reset

public void reset()
Resets the current color transformation to unity, such that all input values in [0,255] map exactly to the same output values in [0,255].

getLUT

public void getLUT(float[] values)
Retrieves the current color transformation. A very low-level routine intended only for use in special situations. For example: 
   ImageAdjuster adjust = new ImageAdjuster(this);
   adjust.contrast(1.5f);
   float [] mylut = new float[256];
   adjust.getLUT(mylut); // store current transformation
   adjust.brightness(g, 0.25f); // high-level call will modify transformation
   adjust.setLUT(mylut); // restore previous transformation

Parameters:
values - An array of 256 floating point values.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - If array is null or length is not exactly 256.
See Also:
setLUT(float [])

setLUT

public void setLUT(float[] values)
Sets the lookup table to user-specified values. A very low-level routine intended only for use in special situations. For example: 
   ImageAdjuster adjust = new ImageAdjuster(this);
   float [] mylut = new float[256];
   for (int i=0; i<256; i++)
     mylut[i] = (float)(255-i); // reverse the raw values, aka "negate"
   adjust.setLUT(mylut);

Parameters:
values - An array of 256 floating point values. Each value should be in the range [0,255]. Values outside that range will be clipped.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - If array is null or length is not exactly 256.
See Also:
getLUT(float [])

mapLUT

public void mapLUT(float[] values)
Maps the current lookup table through user-specified values. A very low-level routine intended only for use in special situations. The value of the user-array is used as an index into the current color transformation. That transformation value is then remapped to the index of the user-array. For example, if user array [0] is 255f, then the current transformation value for color #255 is reassigned to color #0. This can be used to accomplish effects such as posterization, threshold, et cetera, that are not natively supported herein. The important distinction between doing such effects here versus using any of Processing's built-in routines is that they can be accumulated here with other transformations and applied en masse as a single operation. For example: 
   ImageAdjuster adjust = new ImageAdjuster(this);
   adjust.contrast(1.5f);
   float [] mylut = new float[256];
   for (int i=0; i<256; i++)
     mylut[i] = (float)(255-i); // reverse the contrasted values, aka "negate"
   adjust.mapLUT(mylut);  // apply contrast+negate simultaneously

Parameters:
values - An array of 256 floating point values. Each value should be in the range [0,255]. Values outside that range will be clipped.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - If array is null or length is not exactly 256.
See Also:
getLUT(float []), setLUT(float [])

apply

public final void apply(PImage img)
Applies the currently specified color transformation to an entire image. For example: 
   PImage img = loadImage("whatever.jpg");
   ImageAdjuster adjust = new ImageAdjuster(this);
   adjust.brightness(0.5f);
   adjust.contrast(1.25f);
   adjust.apply(img);

Parameters:
img - a PImage or subclass of PImage (f.e. PGraphics)
See Also:
apply(PImage, int, int, int , int)

apply

public final void apply(PImage img,
                        int x,
                        int y,
                        int w,
                        int h)
Applies the currently specified color transformation to the specified area of an image. For example: 
   PImage img = loadImage("whatever.jpg");
   ImageAdjuster adjust = new ImageAdjuster(this);
   adjust.brightness(0.5f);
   adjust.contrast(1.25f);
   adjust.apply(img, 0, 0, img.width/2, img.height/2);

Parameters:
img - a PImage or subclass of PImage (f.e. PGraphics)
x - the left coordinate of the area
y - the top coordinate of the area
w - the width of the area
h - the height of the area
See Also:
apply(PImage)

brightness

public void brightness(float amount)
Applies a brightness adjustment to the current color transformation. This is a low-level routine intended for use when multiple discrete transformations are intended to be concatenated and later applied simultaneously to an image.

Parameters:
amount - The amount of brightness adjustment, typically in the range -1.0 through 1.0, where -1.0 represents full-scale brightness reduction resulting in a completely black result, 0.0 represent no alteration to original brightness, and 1.0 represents full-scale increase resulting in a completely white result. Values outside this range are allowed but will have no further effect.
See Also:
brightness(PImage,float), brightness(PImage,int,int,int,int,float), apply(PImage)

contrast

public void contrast(float amount)
Applies a contrast adjustment to the current color transformation. This is a low-level routine intended for use when multiple discrete transformations are intended to be concatenated and later applied simultaneously to an image.

Parameters:
amount - The amount of contrast adjustment, typically in the range 0.0 through 2.0, where 0.0 represents full-scale contrast reduction resulting in a completely gray result, 1.0 represent no alteration to original contrast, and 2.0 represents a doubling of original contrast. Values outside this range are allowed but are somewhat less useful.
See Also:
contrast(PImage,float), contrast(PImage,int,int,int,int,float), apply(PImage)

gamma

public void gamma(float amount)
Applies a gamma adjustment to the current color transformation. This is a low-level routine intended for use when multiple discrete transformations are intended to be concatenated and later applied simultaneously to an image.

Parameters:
amount - The amount of gamma adjustment, typically in the range 0.0 through 3.0, where 0.0 represents full-scale gamma reduction resulting in a strongly darkened result, 1.0 represent no alteration to original gamma, and 3.0 represents a strong increase in gamma generally brightening the image. Values outside this range are allowed but are somewhat less useful.
See Also:
gamma(PImage,float), gamma(PImage,int,int,int,int,float), apply(PImage)
